summary.p: [1.] Sends, in response to Bullinger's inquiry, a list of new publications from Basel organized by printers for the [Frankfurt Spring] Fair. [2.] A numbered list of books that have arrived from Frankfurt. For any potential book purchases, Bullinger still has a credit outstanding with Gast.

div.p: Greetings. You have rightly and timely reminded about the books to be assigned, which have been published at our place for this fair.
Frobenius published: Commentaries on the Aphorisms of Hippocrates by Brasvola.
He has under the press the Latin Galen, the entire work, and Celius on ancient readings.
Augustine is being reprinted. Isengrinius:
Plutarch's Moralia in Latin. He added some parts that have not been translated so far. This author will be printed in Greek by Frobenius.
Many works by Zasius. Commentaries on Solinus by Münster, shortened, which he has now published for the second time, with added tables.
Valderus: Greek Lexicon.
Urbani's Grammar. Oporinus:
Annotations on various orators of Cicero. New annotations on Valla's Elegances.
Elementale written by Camerarius, etc. He has under the press Theon's Progymnasmata in Greek and Latin.
Theophrastus in Greek, and some booklets on the education of boys. Robert Winter:
Greek Index in Phaborinus' Lexicon. Epitome on the Lives of Plutarch.
Pausanias' Attica and Corinthian in Latin. Some scholastic works by Gilbert Cognatus. Some works by Gesner on herbs.
He has under the press Julius Pollux in Latin and the works of Aristotle corrected by our M. Gemuseus.
Hervagius: Civil Law with great additions.
Herodotus in Greek. He has under the press all of Melanchthon's works arranged in four volumes.
Dr. Albanus: Apicius on culinary matters.
Some poems on the Trojan War. Bryllingerus:
Some comedies taken from the Old and New Testament. New Testament in Greek and Latin.
Valla's work on Elegances. Works of Virgil with Melanchthon's commentaries.
Henricus Petri: Some works of Josephus rendered in Hebrew and Latin, namely apocrypha. All geographical works of Claudius Ptolemy that exist.
Alexander Trallianus with Albanus' scholia. Westhemerus:
Union of dissenters in religion. Poems of Sedulius and Juvencus with commentaries.
Epithets of Ravis. Works of Ringelberg.

Selected elegant letters of Erasmus from the entire volume. From Frankfurt came: 1. Zantis Bible, printed in Cologne. 2. Interpretation against the letter of Pope Paul III, which was given to the emperor. 1540.

3. A sermon on Judas' greed, by Jacob Schenck. 4. An instruction of faith written by Bishop Johannes of Meissen. 5. A question about the true Christian church posed on the 7th article of the protestants, to the emperor's majesty. 6. Prophetic sermon 2 Peter 1, by Vicelius in German. 7. Lazarus the beggar, a comedy by Georgius Macropedius. 8. Catechetical questions by Vicelius. 9. Catechetical examination by Vicelius. 10. An oration to all the princes of the empire about the pope's rise by Baptista Lasdenus. 11. A comforting sermon on the resurrection. Johannes Draconites. 12. Interpretation of the story of Joseph by Corvinus. 13. On the continent cause. Jacobus Scheckius. 14. Comic fables, rebels and aluta. Macropedius. 15. On building matters, book 10 by Leon Battista Alberti of Florence. 16. Syncretism of Germany against the tyranny of the Turks. Nicolaus Wimmannus. 17. On the ordination of bishops. Cochlaeus. 18. Didascalus comedy. Jacobus Zovitius Driescarus. 19. Commentary on the Tungri and Eburones and other peoples of Lower Germany.

Hubertus Thomas Leodius. 20. On the nature, inconveniences, and remedies of raging human anger, 265 questions. M. Otho Körber of Bamberg. 21. Comedy dealing with marriage. Maternus Steindorfer. 22. Three books on the surnames of the gods of the nations by Julianus Aurelius Lessigniensis.

23. Minor Catechism by Urbanus Rhegius. 24. Commentaries on the Epistle to Titus. Christophorus Hofman. 25. Theodoret of Cyrene, bishop, on the knowledge of evangelical truth from Greek and gentile philosophy or on the cure of Greek affections, book 12, interpreted by Zenobio Accialo. 26. Some works by Euricius Cordus on the Kabbalists.

Furthermore, some Hebrew works have been brought from Isny and Paris. Here you have almost the summary of the books I have seen. Farewell in the Lord. There is no need for you to be anxiously troubled about the price when I buy some books for you. For you have sent more so far than I have spent. You know me to be most ready to fulfill your wishes, Gastius.
Your Gastius from the heart.
To the most vigilant pastor of the church of Zurich, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his dearest in the Lord.
